plain_title: Is a newer 'flap' surgical technique better than the standard 'peeling' technique for closing large holes in the retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye)?
key_messages: For people with large holes in the retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye), a newer 'flap' surgical technique probably leads to more successful hole closures than the standard 'peeling' technique. The 'flap' technique may also result in better vision three or more months after surgery. The studies provided little information about unwanted effects.

Because the current findings are based on a small number of studies, larger and better-quality studies are needed to confirm whether the 'flap' technique is better for improving vision and to properly assess its safety.

background.subheading: What is a large macular hole?
background.content: The retina is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye. The central part of the retina, called the macula, is responsible for the sharp, detailed vision needed for reading and driving. A macular hole is a small break in the macula that causes blurred and distorted central vision. This review focuses on 'large' macular holes, which are more difficult to treat successfully.

The standard surgery for a macular hole involves removing the gel-like substance from inside the eye (a vitrectomy) and then peeling away a very thin layer from the surface of the retina, called the internal limiting membrane (ILM). While this 'ILM peeling' technique often works, it is less successful at closing large macular holes. A different surgical technique, known as the 'inverted ILM flap' technique, uses this same membrane to create a flap that helps plug the hole.

background.subheading: What did we want to find out?
background.content: We wanted to compare the two surgical techniques – the inverted ILM flap technique versus conventional ILM peeling – for treating large macular holes. We wanted to know which technique was more effective and safer for improving vision and closing the hole.

methods.content: We searched for studies that compared two surgical techniques for large macular holes: the 'inverted flap' technique versus the standard 'peeling' technique. We then combined the results of these studies and rated our confidence in the evidence.

results.content: The review included four studies with a total of 275 participants from India, Poland, and Mexico. Most participants were women (63%) and older, with an average age ranging from 59.4 to 66 years. All studies enrolled people with large idiopathic macular holes. The follow-up period for the studies ranged from three to twelve months. No study disclosed financial support.

results.subheading: Main results: a new surgical technique compared with standard surgery for large holes in the back of the eye
results.content: The studies compared pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with an inverted internal limiting membrane (ILM) flap against conventional PPV with ILM peeling. Compared to the standard surgery, the new surgical technique probably increases the chance of the hole closing. This new technique may also improve vision three months or more after surgery. It is unclear if the new technique has an effect on vision one month after surgery.

limitations: We have little confidence in the evidence because the studies were very small. It is also possible that people in the studies were aware of which treatment they were getting, and not all of the studies provided data about everything that we were interested in.
currency: The evidence is up to date to December 2022 of search.
